unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Reducing Type I Error
question_text:
A study on womenâ€™s weights was recently completed.
Fifteen randomly selected high school females from an urban setting were compared to $16$ randomly selected high school women from a rural setting. The results are below:
Two-Sample T for Urban Weights vs. Rural Weights

$\text{Difference} = \mu _{\text{Urban Weights}} - \mu_{ \text{Rural Weights}}$
Estimate for difference: $-2.68$ $95\%$ CI for difference: ($-11.45, 6.09$)
T-test of difference = $0$ (vs. not =): T-value = $-0.63$, P-value = $0.537$, DF = $28$
What could be a possible way to reduce the probability of a type I error in this context?

choices.text: Select from different areas across the country to reduce variability.

solution:
A lower alpha level demands strong evidence to make any change. Therefore, it is less likely to commit a type I error and make the change when one should not.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; by increasing alpha, the test becomes more sensitive to any change, therefore reducing the odds of a type II error. However, a type I error would be increased since less evidence is required.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; smaller sample sizes increase the probably of type I and II errors.

Choices 'D' and 'E' are incorrect; two-sample T procedures are based off simple random samples. Furthermore, there is no reason selecting from different areas could reduce variability.
